section.title: Understanding rights and licensing
section.para: The Research & Education Space aggregates data which can be re-used by a wide range of applications, and much of that data describes digital media (such as videos and photographs) which are accessible only to certain groups of people.

To minimise the risk of data being incorporated into the index which applications cannot use, and to ensure an optimum user experience when querying for related media, RES requires that data included in the index includes accurate rights and licensing information.

More specifically, for Linked Open Data to be indexed by the Research & Education Space, it must be published under the terms of a supported license and include explicit licensing data. This approach is aligned with the Open Data Instituteâ€™s guide to publishing machine-readable rights data. This means that any application which uses the RES index is using data documents which are openly-licensed.

However, the data in the index will not necessarily contain rights statements about media (e.g. digital images, videos and audio), even if it contains rights statements about documents which describe that media. Consequently, applications which reuse media, either through embedding or linking, should not bypass any access controls on that media, to ensure that related access rights are not violated.

tip.para: The Research & Education Space was designed so that applications do not have to trust the platform regarding data licensing. As the crawler discriminates based upon the presence of explicit data licensing statements, an application can always verify those statements at source itself, using the same mechanisms employed by the crawler.
